basic.description: This course prepares students for international social-work practice and for transitional work with immigrants, refugees, international migrants, etc. The course also introduces international perspectives in the social-work field and offers varied examples of social-work practice in the U.S., and Western, Central European, and Caribbean nations and examines the impact of the global interdependence on social-work practice and policy and helps students learn to critically analyze varied practice approaches utilized in dealing with international welfare issues.
basic.subject: SOW
basic.title: International Social Work and Social Welfare
